title: 50 Most Notable Yankees Free Agents: Jorge Posada (2007)
description: The Yankees‚Äô slugging catcher hit free agency after a superb 2007, and they had to outbid the Mets to keep him around.
fullText:
When a standout player who has been with your organization his entire career wants to stay with you, you listen. That‚Äôs what Yankees general manager Brian Cashman did when Jorge Posada became a free agent after the 2007 campaign.

A five-time All-Star and switch-hitting Silver Slugger, Posada would‚Äôve been a boon for any team on the market. He still stands as one of the best-hitting catchers of the past 50 years, and his bat was elite in 2007. The Yankees had been able to extend him during the 2001-02 offseason for five years and $51 million with club option, but despite expressing interest in staying with the team he had been with his whole career, there was also major interest from the crosstown New York Mets ‚Äî making the chase for the decorated, switch-hitting backstop all the more interesting.

The Yankees ended up making the deal, paying Posada the most average annual salary for a catcher at the time‚Äî$13.1 million‚Äîand thus stopped a rival team from compelling him to remain in the City, in a different borough. Although the final result being a positive one for the Yankees, it certainly wasn‚Äôt without its fireworks.

Jorge Posada
Signing Date:¬†November 13, 2007
Contract:¬†Four years, $52.4 million

Posada was already an established star by this the fall of 2007, and it had been a remarkable ascent from near-complete anonymity during the early part of the 1990s. We chronicled his history in greater detail during our Top 100 Yankees series, but we‚Äôll present a shorter version. The Santurce, Puerto Rico native starred in high school and was able to cut his teeth some more at Calhoun Community College in Decatur, AL. He landed on the Yankees‚Äô radar, and after a couple draft attempts, they signed him out of the 24th round in the 1990 edition ‚Äî two rounds behind the Yanks‚Äô selection of a young high school lefty from Texas named Andy Pettitte.

Originally a second baseman, Posada was convinced to give catching a try in 1991, when he made 11 appearances behind the plate for short-season Oneonta. By the next year, he was a full-time backstop, and over the next couple seasons, he shot up through the minor leagues, playing 92 games with the Triple-A Columbus Clippers in 1994 and officially debuting with the Yankees in September of ‚Äô95. Blocked at the big-league level across ‚Äô95 and ‚Äô96 by Mike Stanley, Jim Leyritz, and Joe Girardi, Posada played just nine games in The Show during that span, and only traveled with the team as they won it all in October 1996. But even though he would never be confused for a defensive stalwart at catcher, his time would soon come.

Prior to the start of ‚Äô97, the Yankees traded Leyritz to the Angels despite his World Series heroics. They wanted to open the door for Posada to get big-league reps as Girardi‚Äôs backup and were confident that the up-and-comer could earn his keep. Following a 101 OPS+ in 60 games of action in ‚Äô97 though, the Yankees did float Posada as a possible trade option with the Montreal Expos for Cy Young Award winner Pedro Martinez. That obviously did not work out, as Pedro was traded to the rival Boston Red Sox, and the next handful of years would live in infamy between those two teams (and the two players in particular).

Posada finally started over 100 games in the record-breaking ‚Äô98 season for the Yankees, slashing .268/.350/.475 with 17 homers for an OPS+ of 115, and his numbers only continued to climb from there. He was eventually trusted with the everyday job as Girardi aged out of the role and departed in December of ‚Äô99. The 2000 campaign was the first where Posada really shined, making his first All-Star team and hitting .287/.417/.527 with 28 homers and a 139 OPS+, earning his first Silver Slugger as well.

It was an important time for Posada to make his mark, as other members of the Yankees‚Äô core like Paul O‚ÄôNeill and Tino Martinez were nearing the ends of their days in pinstripes. And thanks in part to Posada‚Äôs tenacious at-bat against a dominant Al Leiter with two outs in the ninth inning of 2000 World Series Game 5, the Yankees rallied to secure the three-peat, Posada scoring the go-ahead run on Luis Sojo‚Äôs single.

Although it would be a few years before the Yankees again won it all, Posada was an essential part of the contending operation alongside pal Derek Jeter (the best man in his wedding). Posada earned four consecutive All-Star nods and Silver Sluggers from 2000-03, and he really shined in the last of those years. He became the first Yankees catcher to hit 30 homers in a season since no less than Yogi Berra, and thanks in part to a 144 OPS+ and 5.9 rWAR in 142 games, he finished third for AL MVP, trailing only Alex Rodriguez and Carlos Delgado. And while his 2004-06 seasons weren‚Äôt as decorated, he still played a vital role, remaining a pillar of health with 422 games started out of the possible 486, notching a 121 OPS+.

Entering 2007, Posada had one year left on his deal before he would hit free agency, and in spring training, the Yankees were uninterested in opening up talks on a second extension. He timed his best campaign since ‚Äô03 quite well, and his bat would‚Äôve received even more attention had A-Rod not turned in an MVP season for the ages. Posada finished sixth in the voting with career-highs in all the rate stats, batting .338/.426/.543 with a 153 OPS+ and 5.4 rWAR to claim his fifth All-Star selection and Silver Slugger. That made him a valuable commodity for teams, despite approaching his late thirties at the most physically demanding position in the sport.

The Yankees fell to Cleveland in the ALDS that October, and a decision was on the horizon for Posada. He really wanted a four-year deal in wake of that superb season. The Yankees weren‚Äôt particularly enthused about handing that long a commitment to a catcher who had just turned 37 that August; they were hoping to get Posada on a three-year contract for around $40 million.

So Posada was willing to hear out some of his other options, especially since A-Rod had opted out and longtime manager Torre was on his way to the Dodgers. Most notably, the folks across town were very interested. The 2007 season had ended in disaster for the Mets, and catcher Paul Lo Duca took a serious dip after leading the NL East champs in 2006. He was a free agent as well, but GM Omar Minaya had his eyes on Posada, as did his former third-base coach, Mets manager Willie Randolph.

As such, it was easy for Posada to not-so-subtly get the Yankees‚Äô full attention by meeting with the Mets the day before other clubs could officially submut offers, per the New York Times:

Posada and his agents, Sam and Seth Levinson, had lunch Monday with Minaya and [Mets] vice president Tony Bernazard. The Yankees initially offered the 36-year-old Posada a three-year contract but upped their proposal to four years on Monday evening.

While Posada briefly played hard to get for the Yankees, his intentions were clear from the start. He felt it would be easier to stay with the team that he had been with since his mid-twenties, and that‚Äôs exactly what happened. The Yankees acquiesced to his request and ultimately signed him to a four-year, $52.4 million deal.

In those final four seasons, Posada played in 397 games and slashed .258/.349/.454 for an above-average OPS+ of 110. A shoulder injury curtailed both his and the Yankees‚Äô hopes for 2008 success under his old teammate-turned-skipper Girardi, but in 2009, it all came together. Posada hit 22 homers in 438 PA, good for an .885 OPS and 125 OPS+, and he had a productive October as well. Jeter might‚Äôve been the captain, but Posada unofficially led the clubhouse and was willing to be the guy who held teammates accountable when necessary.

The Bombers won it all, and Posada had his fifth ring. It would be the last one.

Posada‚Äôs bat remained strong in 2010 but his oft-uneven defense had made him a liability behind the plate, and he was a concussion risk as well. The Yankees found a bargain in the more well-balanced Russell Martin that offseason, so they signed him and planned to have Posada DH in 2011. The 40-year-old was unhappy in the role and dipped to a below-average showing at the plate, too. Although it was an awkward swan song for Posada, the hard feelings faded in time (and he was actually one of the few consistent bats during their five-game ALDS loss to Detroit). He retired in January 2012 and the Yankees retired his No. 20 in August 2015, honoring him with a plaque in Monument Park.

So yes, the Yankees had reason to be uneasy about that fourth year. But the overall contract still led to a 2009 World Series crown and the Yankees were able to pivot to a new catcher anyway during that last season. Losing Posada to the Mets would‚Äôve been a true shame; thankfully, they didn‚Äôt let it happen.

See more of the ‚Äú50 Most Notable Yankees Free Agent Signings in 50 Years‚Äù series here.

title: Boost For Inter Milan As PSV Push To Sign Replacement For Winger Linked With Nerazzurri Return
description: Inter Milan‚Äôs hopes of bringing Ivan Perisic back to San Siro may receive a timely boost as developments unfold in the Netherlands.The Nerazzurri remain keen on a return for the Croatian winger, eve...
fullText:
Inter Milan‚Äôs hopes of bringing Ivan Perisic back to San Siro may receive a timely boost as developments unfold in the Netherlands.

The Nerazzurri remain keen on a return for the Croatian winger, even though PSV Eindhoven have so far resisted letting him leave during the January window.

That stance, however, could soon soften, with reports via FCInter1908.

According to Sky Sport, PSV are pushing hard to sign Alphadjo Cisse, a highly rated 2006-born talent owned by Verona and currently impressing on loan at Catanzaro in Serie B.

ZAGREB, CROATIA ‚Äì SEPTEMBER 08: Ivan Perisic of Croatia acknowledges the fans after the team‚Äôs victory in the FIFA World Cup 2026 qualifier match between Croatia and Montenegro at Stadion Maksimir on September 08, 2025 in Zagreb, Croatia. (Photo by Jurij Kodrun/Getty Images)

The Dutch club are reportedly very close to an agreement, a move that could alter the balance of their squad planning.

Cisse‚Äôs profile fits what PSV may soon require.

The young attacker can operate across the frontline and in multiple roles from midfield upwards, including as a wide forward.

His versatility makes him a credible internal solution should PSV decide to reshape their attacking options before the window closes.

For Inter, that situation is worth monitoring closely. The Nerazzurri have made it clear they would welcome Perisic back, valuing his experience, tactical flexibility and familiarity with the environment in Milan.

Until now, PSV‚Äôs refusal to part with the player has represented the main obstacle.

If Cisse does arrive in Eindhoven, the picture could change quickly. PSV would then have greater cover on the flanks, potentially opening the door to negotiations over Perisic.

While no green light has arrived yet, Inter remain attentive.

As the final days of the winter market approach, movements elsewhere could prove decisive. Inter are waiting, and PSV‚Äôs next step may finally unlock the situation.

title: Renato Moicano explains why ‚Äòit‚Äôs impossible‚Äô for Paddy Pimblett to beat Ilia Topuria
description: Pimblett will compete for an interim title in the main event of UFC 324
fullText:
Paddy Pimblett and Ilia Topuria have had a beef since 2022, when the now UFC lightweight champion took offense at online comments regarding the Georgia-Russia war. They got physical prior to that year‚Äôs UFC London show, and it has escalated since.

Pimblett has the chance to win the interim title at UFC 324, when he faces off with Justin Gaethje on Jan. 24 in Las Vegas, and it could lead to a unification bout with Topuria later in 2026.

However, fellow lightweight contender Renato Moicano doesn‚Äôt give Pimblett much of a chance at beating the Georgian-Spanish star.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs impossible. Technique-wise, it‚Äôs very hard,‚Äù Moicano told MMA Fighting. ‚ÄúWatch Topuria, man. At the same time Paddy Pimblett can take a hit in the chin, and Paddy Pimblett has jiu-jitsu, has boxing, he‚Äôs a bad fighter. I don‚Äôt know if you can call him bad, but he‚Äôs a fighter that ‚Äî he‚Äôs not very technical, he‚Äôs not someone you like watching fight, but he‚Äôs beating old men. He beat Bobby Green. I‚Äôd like to see him beat [Mauricio] Ruffy, Topuria, Charles [Oliveira]. Time will tell.‚Äù

Topuria has two 

Moicano said that Pimblett dethroning Topuria could be compared to an all-time upset in the sport: doable, but unlikely.

‚ÄúI saw Michael Bisping beating Luke Rockhold,‚Äù Moicano said. ‚ÄúI saw Matt Serra beat GSP. We saw Chris Weidman beat Anderson Silva. Obviously, maybe the Matt Serra one would look more similar because he‚Äôs a short guy, has jiu-jitsu and all that, but upsets can happen in a fight. It can happen, man. And I hope it does.‚Äù

Moicano was a huge underdog when he took a shot at then-champion Islam Makhachev on a day‚Äôs notice back in January, and explained why he would love a similar upset with a Pimblett championship victory.

‚ÄúI would be very happy if that happened because I like unexpected things, brother,‚Äù Moicano said. ‚ÄúImagine the best fighter in the world losing to Paddy Pimblett? Absolute cinema. I like when the unexpected happen. It would be really cool to see someone like Paddy Pimblett become world champion.‚Äù

title: Crystal Palace vs Brighton rivalry explained: History between Eagles and Seagulls in 'M23 derby' and distance between both clubs
description: Crystal Palace and Brighton have one of the most intense rivalries in English football. Here's the story behind it.
fullText:
Crystal Palace vs Brighton rivalry explained: History between Eagles and Seagulls in 'M23 derby' and distance between both clubs originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The animosity between Crystal Palace and Brighton and Hove Albion is as mystifying to many fans of other clubs as it is intense for the supporters involved in what has become known as the 'M23 derby'.

Palace and Brighton have faced each other more than 100 times since both clubs were formed at the start of the 20th century, but tensions have escalated relatively recently to produce one of the fiercest rivalries in English football.

The Eagles and Seagulls also have one of the closest head-to-head record of any teams involved in a derby with one another, and matches between them have produced a number of epic games over the decades.

Yet fans will notice that the two clubs are not located in close proximity to one another, making this rivalry one of the few heated Premier League clashes that is not based primarily on geographical location.

Here's a look at why the rivalry exists, where it gets its name from, and some of those memorable matches between the clubs.

MORE:¬†Next Premier League manager to leave: Updated odds

While most teams involved in derbies lie in close proximity to each other, Crystal Palace and Brighton's separation of 43 miles means they are not even in the same county.

It would not be hyperbolic, however, to describe their relationship as a footballing hatred ‚Äì and although the sides had regularly played each other in previous years, the venom started during the 1970s.

On the opening day of the 1974/75 season, significant outbreaks of trouble were noted among a crowd of more than 26,000 as a Brighton team managed by Peter Taylor - assistant to Brian Clough the previous season - won 1-0 against a visiting Palace side who had suffered successive relegations.

More than 33,000 people watched Brighton beat Palace 2-0 in February 1976, when home supporters subverted the visitors' 'Eagles' nickname with chants of 'Seagulls' ‚Äì an emblem the club fully adopted two seasons later.

LWT The Big Match
October 1976
Two Clubs That Don‚Äôt Get On!
Brighton 1-1 Crystal Palace
Commentator Brian Moore#BHAFC#CPFCpic.twitter.com/I4IE19UDdp

‚Äî TV Football 1968-92 (@1968Tv) November 14, 2022

Both Brighton and Palace were promoted from what was then known as Division Three at the end of the 1976/77 campaign, but it was a cup tie that stoked the first flames of what has become a fiery mutual contempt.

Inseparable over two first-round FA Cup ties in four days, the clubs faced each other for a third time - replays took place until there was a winner in those days - at Chelsea's Stamford Bridge after several rearrangement efforts had fallen foul of bad weather.

It proved the latest explosive collision between two tough characters: future England boss Terry Venables, as Palace manager, and his former Tottenham teammate, Alan Mullery, guiding Brighton's fortunes.

Crystal Palace manager Terry Venables #cpfc#Palace#Managerspic.twitter.com/TdOybzc4dK

‚Äî Football Memories (@footballmemorys) November 12, 2016

The pair had roomed together at Tottenham but they were rivals for a captaincy that was given to Mullery over Venables by Spurs manager Bill Nicholson.

Palace won the third and final tie between their clubs that season 1-0 but there was controversy when Albion captain Brian Horton's apparent equaliser from a penalty was disallowed by referee Ron Challis, affording opposition goalkeeper Paul Hammond a chance he took to save the retaken spot kick.

Brighton were also aggrieved that a goal by revered striker Peter Ward had been disallowed after Palace took the lead.

Mullery reacted by confronting the referee at full-time, flicking a 'V' sign at the celebrating Palace fans ‚Äì an image that remains iconic to their Brighton counterparts ‚Äì and reputedly throwing his spare change towards the opposition players and staff, adding: ‚ÄúPalace ain‚Äôt worth that."

Do you remember the first time?

The first I can remember is the FA Cup 2nd replay in Dec ‚Äò76. Palace won 1-0 but that‚Äôs only half the story.

A fan launched his cuppa over Mullery, he emptied his pocket, 'That's all you're worth, Crystal Palace!‚Äô

Let the fun begin! pic.twitter.com/HSOQA5lZlq

‚Äî carl (@calciocarl) February 21, 2021

‚ÄúThe lads were all happy that they‚Äôd won," recalled Martin Hinshelwood, a Palace player at the time who would go on to become a highly influential youth coach at Brighton and briefly manage the Seagulls in 2002.

"How we‚Äôd won, I don‚Äôt know," he added to The Athletic. "Brighton deserved to win. There was a bit of banter, then the door opened.

"Alan came in and said, ‚ÄòThis is what I think of you lot‚Äô and threw some coins on the floor. We had one or two heated players in the side and it just went off a little bit.

In 1976-77, Crystal Palace & Brighton played each other 5 times (including 3 FA Cup games!) & bad blood between managers Terry Venables and Alan Mullery spawned a club rivalry.
Here are the programmes from the initial First Round and replay games.#cpfc#bhafc#facuppic.twitter.com/D44dxen8Db

‚Äî Aaron Porter (@AaronPorter) May 27, 2020

"Terry was in the dressing room. Venners was like, ‚ÄòSo what? We won. Unlucky‚Äô. The rivalry started from that. Venners always seemed to outdo Alan.‚Äù

Former England international Mullery, who would have an unsuccessful and unpopular tenure as Palace manager between 1982 and 1984 and a second brief spell at Brighton from 1986, could not have imagined the endless soap opera that he had played a pivotal part in accelerating.

Huge crowds and fighting between groups of fans continued to be features of the games off the pitch, while the teams were frequently involved in promotion tussles in the lower divisions and matches containing drama the like of which scriptwriters might deem too fanciful.

February: Christian Benteke scores a 95th minute winner against Brighton for Crystal Palace

September: Neal Maupay scores a 95th minute equaliser against Crystal Palace for Brighton

The rivalry always delivers. pic.twitter.com/LGAK70zJFH

‚Äî bet365 (@bet365) September 27, 2021

Mullery's Brighton won 3-1 at Newcastle on the final day of the 1978/79 season to earn promotion to the top flight for the first time, but some of the shine was taken off their triumph when Venables' Palace beat them to the title with victory at their Selhurst Park home against Burnley six days later.

Selhurst Park was also the setting for undoubtedly the most extraordinary of the derbies. In 1989, fans had their nerves shattered when five penalties were awarded within 27 minutes of a 2-1 win for Palace.

Only three of those were scored, with Palace goalscoring greats Ian Wright ‚Äì once rejected by Brighton for being too small ‚Äì and Mark Bright each missing one.

Ian Wright on one of his best ever goals for Palace in a classic win over Brighton. üí•üî¥üîµ @IanWright0#cpfc#cpfcfamilypic.twitter.com/GLmBmrWoKk

‚Äî Screaming Alice (@screamingalice1) December 15, 2019

Although Palace were known as 'The Team of the 80s', that remarkable game was one of only three times in 14 attempts when they beat Brighton during the decade, including five successive defeats as part of a wretched run of eight losses and two draws in 10 derbies between 1979 and 1986.

Even though the teams did not meet in the league between 1990 and 2001, Palace were able to enjoy being by far the more successful club during the period, when their achievements included their highest ever finish in the top flight, in 1991, and two promotions from the second tier.

Albion also looked on enviously at Palace's stability off the pitch compared to a period of turmoil for the Sussex side that saw them almost go out of business, leaving their Goldstone Ground home where they had spent 96 years and played many of their matches with Palace across the century.

If it was seen as a mark of Brighton's recovery when they finally got to play Palace again, the wait was worth it only for the home fans at Selhurst Park, whose claims of supremacy across the intervening years were further enhanced by the 5-0 thrashing they handed out on the day, including a hat-trick for future England striker Andy Johnson.

Brighton beat Palace for the first time in almost 17 years with a surprise 1-0 win at Selhurst Park in 2005, but that would precede a run of one win in eight games for them in the fixture.

Palace had the pleasure of becoming the first team to beat Brighton at their new Amex Stadium home in 2011, then repeated the trick with a 2-0 win to prevail by the same score on aggregate in the 2013 Championship playoff semifinals, when Wilfried Zaha scored both goals within 20 second-half minutes.

In 2020, Palace won at Brighton for the first time in the Premier League when Jordan Ayew scored the only goal of the final game many supporters would see before crowds were outlawed during the Covid pandemic.

All of the four subsequent derbies were decided by a goal after the 87th minute, with three of those coming in the 90th minute.

Brighton won the last match between the sides 1-0 in March 2023 and the Seagulls well and truly have bragging rights given their exploits in Europe right now while Palace flounder in the bottom half of the table.

Media coverage occasionally uses the term 'M23 derby' as a nod to the distance between the rivals and the motorway between Brighton and London.

The sporadic use of 'A23 derby' is more accurate, as that is the road directly connecting the areas.

"I'm amazed ‚Äì I can't really believe it's gone on so long," Mullery told BT Sport in 2021, recalling how he had been booed by Palace fans during a ceremony at another of his former sides, Tottenham Hotspur.

Mullery said he had been sent off by the referee after that infamous game, then reacted by telling Palace they were worth less than 30p after having hot coffee poured on his head by an agitator in the stands.

"It's been carried on from person to person to person," he reflected. "It was tough ‚Äì but I'm quite tough at taking whatever someone throws at me."

MORE:¬†Premier League all-time top scorers: Where does Harry Kane rank in history? Can he break the record?

Jim Cannon, who became a Palace legend while playing for them between 1973 and 1988 and marked Ward in that incendiary cup clash, spoke about the rivalry at a club event in 2017.

"The fans, with it being a local derby, just hated one another," he said. "The fans began to really hate one another when we had this long, drawn out cup tie.

"We played in conditions they wouldn't play in today at Stamford Bridge. Mullery threw this five-pound or ten-pound note down and loudly said, 'this is all you lot are worth.' From that day on, the fans just hate Brighton."

title: As Golfweek celebrates its 50th anniversary, relationships still matter
description: As Golfweek celebrates its 50th anniversary, we honor the journey from Charley Stine‚Äôs garage in Winter Haven, Florida, to becoming a global voice in golf.
fullText:
I‚Äôve often told my non-golfing friends that one of life‚Äôs greatest teases is spending an hour or two along 17-Mile Drive ‚Äî that breathtaking stretch of road winding through the Monterey Peninsula. It brushes past legendary courses like Pebble Beach Golf Links, Cypress Point, Spyglass Hill, The Links at Spanish Bay, Monterey Peninsula Country Club, and Poppy Ridge.

For around 12 bucks, even those indifferent to the game can enjoy a scenic sampler of the region, leaving with a phone full of Instagram-worthy shots of some of the most stunning landscapes imaginable.

But for those of us who live to walk mist-covered fairways and strategize our way through the world‚Äôs finest golf holes, the experience is bittersweet. We leave a piece of ourselves behind, wondering if we‚Äôll ever find the time ‚Äî or the access ‚Äî to check off any boxes on this nearly mythical bucket list. The slow cruise is both exhilarating and agonizing. It‚Äôs like being offered a taste of hors d'oeuvres at a Michelin-starred restaurant, only to be shown the door just as the main course begins to emerge from the kitchen.

That was exactly how I felt two decades ago, when my daily concerns revolved around the Buffalo Bills and the Sabres. I was working five nights a week as executive sports editor and lead columnist for a daily newspaper, and two more as a weekend sports anchor on the local ABC affiliate. It was a hectic, uneasy existence, shaped by a city and its struggling franchises ‚Äî post-Jim Kelly, pre-Josh Allen ‚Äî when the Bills were barely a blip on the national sports radar.

Yet every summer, my personal 17-Mile Drive would resurface. The Porter Cup rolled through town, bringing the world‚Äôs top amateur golfers to Niagara Falls Country Club. I‚Äôd mingle with rising stars like Rickie Fowler, Dustin Johnson, Jason Kokrak, Colt Knost, Gary Woodland, and more. The event took over Lewiston, N.Y., the small village where I resided. A friend who hosted players built an indoor hitting bay just for Adam Scott. One rain delay gave me unexpected hours with Billy Horschel, who walked me through the finer points of his game. Tiger Woods and Phil Mickelson had come through just before my time, and Max Homa and Justin Thomas followed after I‚Äôd moved on.

It was a delicious dive into a world I didn‚Äôt experience for most of the year, and when the entire circus left town after a post-tournament party in the backyard of a friend, I was always left wondering what it would be like to follow these young stars each week.

But while the golfers were the main attraction for fans, my eyes each summer turned to Ron Balicki.

Born to a family in public housing in Connecticut, Balicki spent time in Arkansas, but eventually found his way to Florida at a time when the golf scene was rapidly ramping up, and after a dozen years at the daily newspaper near Destin, he was named Golfweek‚Äôs first managing editor in 1983. While others might have used that as a means to focus solely on the pros, Balicki eventually worked his way back into the game‚Äôs grassroots, becoming a legendary college and amateur reporter.

When Balicki died in 2014, Golfweek‚Äôs then managing editor Jeff Babineau (who has also since passed) penned these incredible paragraphs:

Balicki was an ambassador, serving as Golfweek‚Äôs introductory calling card and first handshake to promising amateurs and college players. He not only got to know players, but grew close with their families, too, forging lifelong friendships. Phil Mickelson called him from Doral a few weeks ago to thank Ron for his integrity. When amateur Rickie Fowler decided that he was turning pro in 2009, he stopped mid-practice round and made the one call he knew he needed to make, phoning Balicki.

His span covering the college game dated to the powerhouse teams of Coach Dave Williams at the University of Houston in the 1980s, and he wrote a great deal about the Stanford teams of the mid-90s that included a rising star named Tiger Woods. Every young American champion of the last three decades who has risen through the amateur ranks ‚Äì from Scott Verplank to Davis Love III to Mickelson to Justin Leonard to Woods to Ryan Moore to Fowler ‚Äì was anointed somewhere along his early path with a story carrying a Ron Balicki byline. For years, before the Internet rolled around, he‚Äôd even keep his own stats and scribble out Golfweek‚Äôs weekly college and amateur rankings by hand on tall, yellow legal pads.

Ron Balicki‚Äôs story is foundational to Golfweek‚Äôs existence ‚Äî not just for what he contributed to the game, but for how he did it. He was revered not for bravado, but for depth of knowledge. His legacy is built on longevity, expertise, and humility ‚Äî not bombast.

As Golfweek celebrates its 50th anniversary, we honor the journey from Charley Stine‚Äôs garage in Winter Haven, Florida, to becoming a global voice in golf. Originally printed on paper, Golfweek was the lunchpail-toting publication that mirrored Balicki‚Äôs ground-up approach ‚Äî building trust with players and fans alike. As Curtis Strange recently told me, ‚ÄúWe read all the golf publications, but we couldn‚Äôt wait to get to Golfweek ‚Äî to see the stats from every amateur event and compare ourselves with other players. We had to have it.‚Äù

Five decades later, the spirit of Balicki, Babineau, Stine, and others who shaped this publication lives on. It‚Äôs reflected in Cameron Jourdan‚Äôs extensive amateur golf coverage, Jason Lusk‚Äôs deep dives into courses, David Dusek‚Äôs exhaustive equipment testing, and Eamon Lynch‚Äôs incisive columns. And while Beth Ann Nichols and Adam Schupak lead our extensive pro tour coverage, Golfweek remains committed to celebrating the entire game ‚Äî not just when the purses are biggest.

These relationships endure. I was reminded of that at this year‚Äôs Valero Texas Open, when Brian Harman lit up recalling his 2007 Porter Cup win ‚Äî a record-setting performance that still tops the event's all-time leaderboard. Or when I heard a touching story from the family who housed Horschel during his amateur days near my hometown. Soon after the family patriarch passed away, Horschel won the 2014 FedEx Cup, a moment that changed his career‚Äôs trajectory. Yet he found the time to quickly text them a photo of the trophy, adding, ‚ÄúThis one‚Äôs for your dad.‚Äù

Golfweek‚Äôs 50th anniversary isn‚Äôt just a milestone ‚Äî it‚Äôs a tribute to the relationships, stories, and spirit that have defined the publication for half a century. And it‚Äôs a promise that those values will continue to guide us into the next.

Tim Schmitt is the managing editor of Golfweek, and has just two of the 17-Mile Drive courses crossed off his list.

This article originally appeared on Golfweek: Golfweek at 50: Relationships still matter

title: Bristol edge past Exeter in rainstorm to go third
description: Torrential rain meant that only eleven points were scored all match.
fullText:
Bristol Bears leapfrogged Exeter Chiefs to move up to third in the Prem table with a hard-fought 8-3 win in appalling conditions at Sandy Park.

With the rain teeming down, the first half was largely punctuated by handling errors and referee Karl Dickson's whistle, with neither side able to get points on the board until Henry Slade's penalty just before the half-hour mark.

The game's only try then came through Noah Heward's sliding effort, after Olly Woodburn was unable to gather the ball as half-time approached.

In what had looked increasingly like a scoreless second half, James Williams' late penalty condemned Rob Baxter's men to their first home defeat of the season.

In a match that was meant to herald the long-awaited returns of Bears stalwarts Steven Luatua and Gabriel Ibitoye, all the focus was on the conditions, with neither team able to produce the running rugby so desired by both fan bases.

Barely able to see through the rain, both sides adopted a hard yards and box kicking approach in the first half, one that failed to deliver any real attacking momentum for either until the dying moments of the first half.

It was Slade who stepped up, converting a penalty, minutes after Tom Jordan had squandered a similar opportunity for Bristol at the other end.

In a game desperately crying out for points, Slade was then forced to dot the ball down under his own posts after Woodburn's mishandling led to the ball squirming out on the liquid surface.

From the ensuing scrum, Bristol eventually capitalised.

Slade was lucky not to be penalised when he knocked on as he attempted to intercept a pass meant for Matias Moroni deep in the Chiefs' 22.

But Louis Rees-Zammit was able to pick up the ball and find space on the outside to feed Heward, who slid in for what turned out to be the only try of the game.

With the rain easing as the second half began, Exeter drove up into the Bears' 22, but were unable to break through the impervious Bristol defence, eventually being penalised after Gabriel Oghre had stolen the ball back.

Slade then had the chance to put Exeter ahead for the first time, but his penalty from the halfway line drifted agonisingly wide.

The Chiefs had the majority of the ball but were unable to capitalise and it was the Bears who looked most like scoring when Rees-Zammit counter-attacked, only for his grubber kick forward to drift long, allowing Woodburn to recover.

The home side then paid for their profligacy.

Slade's up and under was charged down in midfield, forcing the England centre to dive on the loose ball before being penalised for holding on.

Williams then made no mistake, slotting the ensuing penalty through the posts as Bristol left Sandy Park sodden, but victorious.

The result leaves Exeter in fifth on 35 points, following Leicester's 34-7 win over Harlequins.

Van Poortvliet shines as Leicester dominate Quins

Eleven-try Saracens thump Newcastle Red Bulls

Bristol Bears' director of rugby Pat Lam told BBC Radio Bristol:

"The beauty of the weather is that it was black and white, we had to roll our sleeves up and commit to everything.

"The physicality, the getting up off the ground, making another tackle, the defensive sets we had were brilliant, not just to defend but also not to give away penalties.

"We're really showing that we can win in lots of ways - there is more to this team than just throwing the ball around.

"To win eight games out of the last nine is brilliant, absolutely brilliant."

Exeter Chiefs' director of rugby Rob Baxter told BBC Radio Devon:

"We made quite a lot of errors, there's a lot of things for us to look at that we could've done better, but the Bears made a lot of errors as well.

"In a very tight game, they probably shaded the areas that win and lose games. Their mistakes hurt them less than ours did.

"We didn't quite finish things off, they defended their line really strongly, we weren't quite good enough today, let's move on."

Exeter: Woodburn; Feyi-Waboso, Slade, Haydon-Wood, Brown-Bampoe; Skinner, Chapman; Sio, Dweba, Tchumbadze; Jenkins (c), Zambonin, Hooper, Roots, Fisilau.

Replacements: Yeandle, Goodrick-Clarke, Roots, Pearson, Capstick, Cairns, Hammersley, Ridl.

Bristol: Rees-Zammit; Heward, Moroni, Janse van Rensburg, Ravouvou; Jordan, Randall; Genge, Oghre, Kloska; Rubiolo, Batley, Luatua, Harding (c), Mata.

Replacements: Thacker, Lahiff, Halliwell, Owen, Grondona, Marmion, Williams, Ibitoye.

title: Tennessee vs Alabama Prediction, Picks & Odds for Tonight's College Basketball Game
description: Get the best Tennessee vs. Alabama predictions ahead of Saturday's matchup in Tuscaloosa. Free college basketball picks for January 24.
fullText:
The Tennessee Volunteers look to get their season back on track as they head to Tuscaloosa for a showdown with the No. 17 Alabama Crimson Tide.

Tennessee has lost three of its last five, but that slide can‚Äôt be pinned on five-star freshman Nate Ament, who I‚Äôm backing to have a big game in my Tennessee vs. Alabama predictions.

Here are my best free college basketball picks for this conference clash on Saturday, January 24.

Tennessee vs Alabama best bet: Nate Ament Over 15.5 points (-120)

Tennessee forward Nate Ament is averaging 15.4 points and 6.3 rebounds per game and has shown improved efficiency of late. The silky-smooth 6-foot-10 freshman is shooting 49.1% from the field over his last six games after connecting at just a 38% clip across his first 12 contests.

Ament has scored 17 or more points in three straight games and draws a favorable matchup tonight against an Alabama team that plays at a blazing-fast pace while offering little resistance on defense.

The Crimson Tide are 329th nationally in points allowed per game (82.6), with that number ballooning to 86.8 against high-major opponents. They also sit outside the top 300 in free throws allowed per game (25.2), while Ament ranks in the top 15th percentile in free-throw rate.

Ament‚Äôs ability to score in transition and consistently get to the line should help him eclipse his points total tonight.

Let‚Äôs also back Ament to have a productive night on the glass, as Alabama‚Äôs extremely fast tempo has the Tide ranked 358th in rebounds allowed per game (41.3).

Tennessee hasn‚Äôt looked great of late, but neither has Alabama, which is 2‚Äì7 ATS in its last nine games against Top-100 KenPom opponents at home. The Vols check in at No. 23 at KenPom and are 14th in adjusted defensive efficiency.

Tennessee would have a solid chance to cover this spread even if the Tide were at full strength, and that may not be the case. Alabama‚Äôs second- and third-leading scorers, Aden Holloway and Amari Allen, have both been downgraded to questionable for tonight.

With the Tide possibly missing their second and third-highest scorers against a strong Vols defense, I'm leaning towards the Under on a lofty total.

The Under has cashed in 10 of 12 meetings between these SEC foes during Rick Barnes' tenure.

Spread: Tennessee +6.5 (-110) | Alabama -6.5 (-110)

Moneyline: Tennessee +230 | Alabama -280

Over/Under: Over 167.5 (-110) | Under 167.5 (-110)

The Vols have gone 4-0 SU and 3-1 ATS in the last four meetings between these conference foes. Find more college basketball betting trends for Tennessee vs. Alabama.

Coleman Coliseum, Tuscaloosa, AL

Odds are correct at the time of publishing and are subject to change.
Not intended for use in MA.
